query.query: {"measures":[["sum","Amount","A",{"display":"Totals"}]],"columns":[{"query":{"measures":[["sum","Amount"]],"groups":[["Close_Date_Year","Close_Date_Month"]],"formula":"sum(B) over ([..0] partition by all order by ('Close_Date_Year~~~Close_Date_Month'))","filters":[["Closed",["TRUE"],"in"]]},"header":"Totals"},{"query":{"measures":[["sum","Amount"]],"groups":[["Close_Date_Year","Close_Date_Month"]],"filters":[["Closed",["TRUE"],"in"]]}}],"groups":[["Close_Date_Year","Close_Date_Month"]]}

parameters.text: Click into these charts to dive into the details.

Heat maps use color density to show concentration. In this case, a darker color means more opportunities. Heat maps can only have a single measure.

Want to see more than one dimension? Try a matrix chart, which is like the offspring of a heat map and a scatter plot. (There's nothing more beautiful than the love between two chart types.)

Matrix charts show distribution by color density and bubble size. In the below example, size represents sales, and color the number of opportunities. Matrix charts can have up to two measures. When building the chart, change the order of measures to swap color and size.
See where opportunities are concentrated across industry and segment.

Heat maps, matrix, and other distribution charts help you visualize volume distribution so you can make decisions about concentration and whitespace. Too many eggs in one basket? Vast stretches of zero penetration? Find out, with a distribution chart.

This example helps you quickly see where your opportunities fall... and where they don't. I'm looking at you, Enterprise Energy.
Learn which chart types are best for visualizing your data
See where you may be missing out in both sales and opportunities by product and country, then plot your next move.
